The '''Washington University Bears''' are the athletic teams of [[Washington University in St. Louis]], located in [[St. Louis, Missouri]]. Washington University is currently a member of the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] at the [[Division III (NCAA)|NCAA Division III]] level. The Bears compete in the [[University Athletic Association]] (UAA).
The Bears have won 18 NCAA Division III Championshipsâone in men's [[tennis]] (2008), two in men's [[basketball]] (2008, 2009), five in women's [[basketball]] (1998â2001, 2010),<ref name="bearsports.wustl.edu">{{cite web | title=Women's Basketball | url=http://bearsports.wustl.edu/womensbball/womensbball.html | work=[http://bearsports.wustl.edu Washington University Athletics]}}</ref> and ten in women's [[volleyball]] (1989, 1991â1996, 2003, 2007, 2009)<ref name="http">{{cite web | title=Volleyball | url=http://bearsports.wustl.edu/volleyball/volleyball.html | work=[http://bearsports.wustl.edu Washington University Athletics]}}</ref> â and 139 [[University Athletic Association|UAA]] titles in 15 different sports.<ref>{{cite web | title=Athletic Titles | url=http://bearsports.wustl.edu/titles.html | work=[http://bearsports.wustl.edu Washington University Athletics]}}</ref>
The Athletic Department is headed by John Schael who has served as [[Athletic director|director of athletics]] since 1978. The 2000 [[Division III (NCAA)|Division III]] Central Region winner of the National Association of Collegiate Directors of Athletics/Continental Airlines Athletics Director of the Year award,<ref name="John Schael">{{cite web | title=John Schael | url=http://bearsports.wustl.edu/staff/schael.html | work=[http://bearsports.wustl.edu Washington University Athletics]}}</ref> Schael has helped orchestrate the Bears athletics transformation into one of the top departments in Division III.<ref name="John Schael" />

=== Basketball ===
In 2009 and 2007 both the men's and women's basketball teams made the Final Four.
==== Men's Basketball ==== In Men's Basketball, WUSTL repeated as national champions in 2009, defeating [[Richard Stockton College]] 61â52. In 2008, WashU defeated [[Amherst College|Amherst]] 90â68 to win the university's first men's basketball national championship. WUSTL lost to [[Virginia Wesleyan College]] in the 2007 NCAA Final Four, but defeated [[The College of Wooster|Wooster]] in the third place game. In 2009, Junior guard Aaron Thompson, senior forward Tyler Nading, and senior point guard Sean Wallis (also ''[[Jewish Sports Review]]'' All-American)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bearsports.wustl.edu/releases/mbk5-6-10.html |title=Washington University Athletics |publisher=Bearsports.wustl.edu |date=2010-05-06 |accessdate=2010-08-08}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> of the 2009 NCAA Division III National Champion menâs basketball team were named to the DIII News All-America Team, as announced by the publication.<ref name="bearsports.wustl.edu" /> In 2007, Junior forward Troy Ruths earned first-team All-America honors by DIII News, third-team accolades by the [[National Association of Basketball Coaches|NABC]], and honorable-mention honors by [[D3hoops.com]].<ref name="bearsports.wustl.edu" />
==== Women's Basketball ==== Women's basketball is the current [[NCAA Women's Division III Basketball Championship]] defending champions and has won four consecutive national titles from 1998â2001, during which time they established what was then the longest winning streak in NCAA women's basketball history, at 81 games. On March 20, 2010, WUSTL defeated [[Hope College]] 65â59 in the 2010 national championship game.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bearsports.wustl.edu/releases/wbk3-20-10.html |title=Washington University Athletics |publisher=Bearsports.wustl.edu |date=2010-03-20 |accessdate=2010-08-08}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Women's basketball has made the championship game three out of the past four years, losing to [[DePauw University]] in 2007 55-52 and in 2009 losing to [[George Fox University]] 65-53.<ref name="bearsports.wustl.edu" /> Women's basketball won the DIII championship four straight seasons from 1999-2001.<ref>[http://www.ncaa.com/history/default.aspx?id=87936 ]{{dead link|date=August 2010}}</ref> The team is coached by [[Nancy Fahey]], who has been at Wash U since 1986. In addition to the 5 National Championships under Fahey, the Bears have appeared in the NCAA DIII National Tournament 21 straight seasons from 1989-2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bearsports.wustl.edu/womensbball/womensbballcoach.html |title=Washington University Athletics |publisher=Bearsports.wustl.edu |date= |accessdate=2010-08-08}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
=== Cross Country === The cross country teams are managed by head coach Jeff Stiles. The women placed third at the 2007 NCAA Division III Championship meet. The Bears also ran to third-place finishes at the 2005 and 2004 NCAA Division III Championships. Washington U. came in fourth place at the 2006 NCAA Championships. The women also won their third-straight Midwest Region title in 2007. In 2009, after going unranked all year, the men qualified for the National Championship and finished seventh place at the National meet. All told, the men's and women's cross country teams have won 13 UAA titles (nine women, four men), qualified as a team for the NCAA Championships 12 times (seven women, five men) and sent 32 individual qualifiers to the Championships. Since 1997, the Bears have also produced 12 All-Americans; seven individuals have combined to total All-America 11 honors{{Citation needed|date=October 2007}}.
=== Football === {{Main|Washington University Bears football}}
===Roller Hockey=== The men's roller hockey team has made the [[National Collegiate Roller Hockey Association]] (NCRHA) national tournament in consecutive years from 2005â2008, finishing as high as 3rd in the nation for Division II in 2005.<ref>{{cite web | title=NCRHA | url=http://www.ncrha.org/team.php?team_id=50611&area=schedule}}</ref>
=== Men's Soccer === Having made 17 [[NCAA Men's Soccer Championship|NCAA Tournament]] appearances, the WUSTL's men's [[soccer]] program is one of the nation's most storied. Since the inception of the [[Division III (NCAA)|Division III]] tournament in 1974, the Bears have finished as national runners-up three times (1978, 1985, 1987). The Bears have also posted a 22â16â4 [[NCAA]] Tournament record (.585). The Bears have endured just three losing seasons out of the last 18, and none since 1994. [[Washington University]] has a 193â91â26 (.665) record over that span, including five [[NCAA]] Tournament appearances, two [[University Athletic Association]] (UAA) titles and a Division III [[Final Four]] appearance in 1997.<ref>{{cite web | title=Womens Soccer | url=http://bearsports.wustl.edu/womenssoccer/womenssoccerhistory.html | work=[http://bearsports.wustl.edu Washington University Athletics]}}</ref>
===Cricket=== There has been an on again off again cricket team.
=== Women's Soccer === The women's soccer team has made seven NCAA appearances and captured five UAA Championships. They were the runner up at the NCAA Division III Championship
===Softball=== Since the inception of the Washington University softball program in 2000, the team has captured five UAA championships and has made six consecutive trips to the NCAA Tournament, including its 2007 College World Series runner-up finish.<ref>2007 Washington University Softball Media Guide</ref>
=== Swimming and Diving === The Swimming and Diving teams are led by eight year head coach Brad Shively. In 2009, the Washington University men's and women's swimming teams combined to break four school records on the final day of the 2009 NCAA Division III Swimming and Diving Championships as the WU men placed seventh overall and the women came in 14th place. In 2005â2006, Shively led the Red and Green to their top finishes in program history. The women placed fifth at the NCAA Championships, while the men took sixth. Additionally, Seniors Michael Slavik (24-time All-American) and Eric Triebe (26-time All-American) won the first (50 free â 20.46 Michael Slavik) and second (200 free â 1:39.12 Eric Triebe) individual national titles in Washington University history.<ref>[http://d3swimming.com/results/results-view.php?type=Finals&meetid=398 d3swimming.com: 2006 Men's NCAA Division III National Championships: Finals<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Since 1979, 56 Bears student-athletes have earned 304 All-America citations. Additionally, the women's team has produced a composite dual meet record of 165â57, while the men's team has compiled a 144â90 mark.<ref>{{cite web | title=Volleyball | url=http://bearsports.wustl.edu/swimdive/swimdivehistory.html | work=[http://bearsports.wustl.edu Washington University Athletics]}}</ref>
=== Volleyball === WUSTL women's volleyball team has enjoyed the most success in the sport's history earning national championships in 1989, 1991, 1992, 1993, 1994, 1995, 1996, 2003, 2007, and 2009. In 2009, the Bears defeated [[Juniata College]] 3â1 in the Championship game.<ref name="http" />

== Facilities ==
=== Francis Field === [[Image:238038658 c62059dc1f b.jpg|left|thumb|Gates at Francis Field]]
Washington University in St. Louis is home of [[Francis Field (St. Louis)|Francis Field]], site of the [[1904 Summer Olympics]]. [[Francis Field (St. Louis)|Francis Field]] is also home of the [[Washington University in St. Louis Football]], Soccer, and [[Track and field|Track and Field]] teams.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bearsports.wustl.edu/facilities/FrancisField.html |title=Washington University Athletics |publisher=Bearsports.wustl.edu |date= |accessdate=2010-08-08}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
=== Washington University Field House === The [[Washington University Field House]] is a 3,000-seat, {{convert|17250|sqft|m2}}, multi-purpose [[arena]] located on the Wash U. campus. The Field House serves as the home for Bears men's and women's basketball teams and the volleyball team.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bearsports.wustl.edu/facilities/FieldHouse.html |title=Washington University Athletics |publisher=Bearsports.wustl.edu |date= |accessdate=2010-08-08}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
=== Kelly Field === [[Kelly Field (St. Louis)|Kelly Field]] serves as the home for Washington University Bears baseball.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bearsports.wustl.edu/facilities/KellyField.html |title=Washington University Athletics |publisher=Bearsports.wustl.edu |date=2005-04-01 |accessdate=2010-08-08}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
=== Francis Gymnasium === [[Francis Gymnasium (St. Louis)|Francis Gymnasium]] was built for the [[Louisiana Purchase Exposition|1904 World's Fair]] and [[1904 Summer Olympics]] and is currently part of the Athletic Complex. It now houses Millstone pool, an Olympic sized pool constructed in 1985.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bearsports.wustl.edu/facilities/MillstonePool.html |title=Washington University Athletics |publisher=Bearsports.wustl.edu |date= |accessdate=2010-08-08}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
